MALAYSIA AGREEMENT


    Order read for resuming adjourned debate on Amendment [31st July, 1963] to Question [30th July, 1963].

    Mr Speaker: The Original Question was as appears in a further amended notice of motion+ copies of which are with hon. Members:

    `+ In pursuance of the resolution of this House taken on the 10th June, 1963 that there should be an early settlement fair and just to both sides on the basis of the terms of the White Paper (Paper Cmd. 33 of 1961) and mindful of the long and arduous battle for merger, this House

WELCOMES the successful outcome in the final agreement reached in London on 9th July, 1963, which agreement contains the terms in the said White Paper with amendments made on a quid pro quo basis, Singapore getting a Malaysian Common Market written into the Constitution in return for a percentage of Singapore's revenue of national taxes instead of an annual lump sum as contribution for Federal services in Singapore, and

TAKING COGNIZANCE of the exchange of memoranda on the financial arrangements as in Paper Misc. 4 of 1963 which sets out the basis on which the Singapore and Federation Governments arrived at their respective percentages and the component parts thereof, and

SUBJECT to the fulfilment of the conditions set out in the exchange of letters between the Singapore Government and the Federation Government and the Singapore Government and the British Government contained in Paper Misc. 5 of 1963, this House

ADOPTS the constitutional provisions and amendments contained in Paper Cmd. 22 of 1963 and the amendments thereof contained in Paper Cmd. 24 of 1963.'.

Since which an amendment has been moved:

    `To leave out from "1961)" in line 4 to the end and insert -

Column: 577



    "this House noting that the agreement made between the People's Action Party Government, the United Kingdom Government and the Federation of Malaya Government in London on 9th July, 1963, is at variance with Paper Cmd. 33 of 1961,

    (i) condemns the Government for signing such an agreement;

    (ii) demands that the Government immediately repudiate the said agreement; and

    (iii) urges that a general election be held fairly conducted under the supervision of the United Nations in order that the people may elect their new representatives for fresh constitutional talks with the United Kingdom Government.".'

The Question is, "That the words proposed to be left out, be left out."

    Hon. Members are aware that the Member for Farrer Park has indicated that at the appropriate time he will move an amendment. I have received an amended notice of his amendment copies of which are with Members. The amendment reads:

    At the end, to add -

    "save and except Article 30 (2) (b) in page 144 (Terms of office of Members) and provided that appropriate steps be taken to amend firstly Article 69 in page 47 (Safeguards for constitutional position of Singapore) to provide for the initial concurrence of this Legislative Assembly by a two-thirds majority, and secondly to Article 33 in page 145 (Filling of vacancies) to provide for the filling of vacancies within three months."

I have indicated before that the debate may range over not only the original Motion but also the two amendments.

2.40 p.m.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): Mr Speaker. Sir, the motion before the House is of grave national importance demanding serious consideration. The Prime Minister made a three-hour speech. The Opposition listened in silence because we were aware of the importance of this national issue. We accorded, and quite rightly, due respect to the Prime Minister for his grave pronouncements by listening in silence and with great attention for three hours. We did not leave the Chamber other than to attend to the call of nature. We did not interject but allowed him to make his lengthy speech although at times he found occasion to

Column: 578

rub in harsh words against some Members of the Opposition. This is typical of the P.A.P. culture. He levelled a lot of vicious remarks against me personally, vicious not in the language used but vicious in the intent such personal remarks were meant to convey. I will reply to some of them later on in my speech.

    The Member for Queenstown was the next speaker because he had given notice of his intention to move an amendment. He started speaking at about 6.20 p.m. and he was still speaking up to the moment of interruption at 12 midnight. In fact, he spoke in all for 6½ hours. As was to be expected, Sir, there were less and less Members remaining in the Chamber and for some length of time all the Government Ministers were not in the Chamber. There was even a time when there were only two Government Back-benchers. This clearly shows to the Opposition and to the public the disrespect the Government Benches including the Ministers, have for this grave national issue that was being debated. They behaved in a very irresponsible manner in their treatment of the national issue. At 11.30 p.m. that night, the Prime Minister and his obedient Minister for Finance walked into the Chamber. They were well dressed and were, in fact, sporting button-holes. Their faces were red, showing evidence of their having had a boisterous time. In fact, they had just finished a dinner given to them in their honour by the Chambers of Commerce in their belief that with common market big money can become bigger.

    As soon as they stepped into the Chamber, Sir, the dignity of the House was insulted and they had to be pulled up on several occasions by the Deputy Speaker. I stood up on a point of order. I said that the Opposition gave the Prime Minister all due attention and respect during the Prime Minister's three-hour long speech. I called on the Prime Minister and his obedient Minister for Finance to accord the same measure of attention and respect to the Opposition. In an undertone, the Prime Minister remarked that I was siding with the Barisan Sosialis. I was not siding with anybody. I was just standing up for the

Column: 579

dignity of the House. The Prime Minister left the Chamber soon after this, but the Minister for Finance remained behind and his conduct was grossly disorderly. He made loud yawning noises and he muttered some rude remarks as he left the Chamber. As he left his seat to walk to the Bar, he made some very rude remarks.

    An hon. Member: What remarks?

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: The remarks, Sir, are in the Official Report.

    Mr David Marshall (Anson): On a point of order, Mr Speaker, Sir. We are all accustomed to P.A.P. manners. But is this part of the very grave motion before the House which has only till midnight?

    Mr Speaker: I have always allowed exordiums. I think the Member for Cairnhill knows that there is a guillotine and I think he will probably make due allowance for that.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Thank you, Mr Speaker. I was just trying to point out to the House and to the public the irresponsible manner that Ministers of the Government have been behaving towards this national issue. I will not quote the Hansard in order to cut down time. As the Finance Minister was leaving his seat, he muttered some rather rude remarks. Quite rightly, the Deputy Speaker pulled him up on a point of order. And he left the Chamber. Sir, I would have stood up under Standing Order 55.

    Mr Speaker: Order. There, I think, I must stop the Member for Cairnhill because the application of Standing Order No. 55 would be within the purview, or jurisdiction, of the Deputy Speaker who was then pursue this point because it could be construed as being a reflection on the Chair.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: I quite understand that, Sir, but let it be. I should have stood up under Standing Order 55, but at that time I was thinking of Article 30

Column: 580

(2)(b) - the P.A.P. might take action against its Member and we might Jose the services of a very good and efficient Deputy Speaker.

    Mr John Mammen (Telok Blangah): I would like to make a point of clarification.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock resumed his seat.

    Mr John Mammen: The Member for Cairnhill has imputed that I, being a Member of the Party in power, was afraid of losing my seat because of section -

    Mr Speaker: Order. I do not think the Member for Cairnhill ever imputed that. If he did impute that, then I am afraid he might be called before the Committee of Privileges. I do not think that is a fair construction of what the Member for Cairnhill is trying to drive at. I would suggest to the Member for Cairnhill that he has made his point.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Thank you. Sir. In fact, I have very great respect for the Deputy Speaker, Sir. He has done a marvelous piece of work under sometimes trying conditions.

    Sir, we had hoped that we would be guided by the wisdom of the Minister for Finance in regard to the loan agreement and the Common Market. The Prime Minister in his opening speech gave the Opposition a clear indication that his colleague, the Minister for Finance, who bore the brunt of detailed work, would speak on this aspect of the Agreement. Unfortunately the Minister for Finance was too busy during the few times he was in the Chamber interjecting and displaying disorderly conduct. Therefore, we lost the opportunity of being guided by him in our consideration of the agreement reached in regard to the loan agreement and the Common Market. I hope his silence so far is not due to the fact that he has been having some disquieting moments that make him fight shy of discharging this very important duty imposed on him by his master, the Prime Minister.

Column: 581



    Sir, I now come to the important point that has been raised by my colleague, the Member for Farrer Park. The motion before the House, or shall we say, the documents that are for adoption, can be divided into four parts: (1) the implementation of the White Paper Cmd. 33 of 1961, (2) the loan agreement, (3) the Common Market, and (4) the constitutional matters affecting Singapore. On (1) , the White Paper Cmd. 33, the Alliance has given its full support and we are with the Government on this. There can be no charge whatsoever that we are not standing up to the stand that we took on Paper Cmd. 33. We gave the Government the mandate. They went to London and discharged it. The Member for Farrer Park has already expressed suitable appreciation of the discharge of that mandate.

    In regard to (2) , the loan agreement, and (3) the Common Market, these are matters that had not been discussed in this Assembly at all. These are matters on which the Government has received no mandate. If the Government is really conscious of its strength in the Assembly, it should have consulted the Legislative Assembly on these two important aspects of the Malaysia Agreement, and received a mandate. But the Government, being a dictatorial Government, just could not care less. They thought they had all the brains with them and could go ahead. Be that as it may, we are for Malaysia. We are prepared to support the loan agreement and the Common Market. But we would have been in a much better position to speak on these two aspects of the Malaysia Agreement had the Minister for Finance deigned or condescended to let us have the wisdom of his knowledge of such economic matters.

    But the most important objection which we have, and still have, despite the explanation given by the Leader of the House and the Minister for Law, are the three main points which are the subject of a proposed amendment by the Member for Farrer Park on behalf of the Alliance. The first point, Sir, is in relation to Article 69 of the Malaysia Act, which is found at page 47 of Paper Cmd.

Column: 582

22. We objected to this on the ground that any amendment to the Constitution should receive the concurrence of the Legislative Assembly in the proportion as is enshrined in Article 90 of the Singapore Constitution (at page 161). In the Singapore Constitution, it is laid down that no amendment shall be made "unless it has been supported on Second and Third Readings by the votes of not less than two-thirds of the total number of members thereof". The Deputy Prime Minister and the Minister for Law stood up and explained, "That particular clause is in the Malaysia Act, and under the Federation Constitution it will require that same number of votes before it can become law." That we understand, but we in Singapore maintain that the Constitution of Singapore, in so far as such important measures as citizenship are concerned, shall not be left to just the Central Parliament with only the concurrence of the Governor, that is to say, the government of the day. A matter of such grave character should quite rightly so come under the same requirement as Article 90 of the Singapore Constitution. Then the Minister for Law said, "Oh, look at sections 69 and 66. They are the same. Section 66 is for Borneo and Sarawak. It is the same. Why all the argument?" Section 66 refers to Borneo and Sarawak, and they are coming into Malaysia on different terms - on more or less "complete" merger than Singapore. Therefore, the constitutional arrangements with Borneo and Sarawak should not be applied to Singapore because we have autonomy in a number of important subjects. Perhaps the Government will reconsider this position. An amendment to the constitution affecting rights of citizenship, Article 69, should not come into force despite its having gone through the Central Parliament on a two-thirds majority vote without the concurrence of the Singapore Legislature on the same number of votes, i.e., a two-thirds majority. I hope the Government will reconsider that.

    We who have been described by the Government as taking orders - it was distorted to the extent that we take orders - say that that is the kind of

Column: 583

order the Government of Singapore cannot take. It must be the Legislative Assembly of Singapore after having duly debated whether or not any amendment to the Constitution in regard to citizenship shall or shall not be adopted.

    Sir, on the second Article, i.e. 30 (2) (b) - before I come to that, Sir, let me say this. The Deputy Prime Minister said. "Oh, this is the Malaysia Act. Section 69 is for the Malaysia Central Parliament. It is not for us to decide." Perhaps he has not got the advantage of advice from his colleague, the Minister for Law. No doubt this is the Malaysia Act, but the Federal Government would not have dared to put that in for the consideration of Parliament without consent Of agreement of the Singapore team. "This is quite all right. The Federal Government can go ahead with this amendment." The P.A.P. accepted it, otherwise it could not have been in. Therefore, we are trying to tell the P.A.P. Government that what they have done on this is not good for the people of Singapore. We, who know that we will be the next Government of Singapore - and this will be exercised by us - yet say that it is wrong.

    Coming to (2), Sir, this is the real nigger in the woodpile. Article 30 (2) (b) that is in the Singapore Constitution, that is in page 144. The Deputy Prime Minister stood up and tried to explain it away. The Member for Farrer Park said, "Ah, ha, there is some jiggery-pokery going on." Yes, why is this? That this Article 30 does not read in the same manner as the Article 30 in the Blue Book? The Deputy Prime Minister again, not having had the advice of the Minister for Law, jumped up and said. "Oh this Blue Book is nothing. This is the thing that counts. And if we approve it, the Queen will just sign it as an Order in Council." Sir, if one will take the trouble to examine the Blue Book and the White Book - white because it is P.A.P., so they say it must be white - you will see that word for word and even the numbering, everything is the same except where there has been the jiggery-pokery of the P.A.P.; something

Column: 584

is put in there that is not here. Surely the Deputy Prime Minister is not going to suggest that there was no full discussion in London as to the wording of each and every Article; even the punctuation sometimes was discussed. So there had been that discussion in London, that acceptance in London. Perhaps the Government, represented by the Prime Minister and his very able servant, the Minister for Finance, did bring this up in London, and because it is not in the London copy, then it could be that it must have been rejected by the London Ministers, rejected no doubt on the ground that this is unheard of. It is contrary to parliamentary practice throughout the world. To suggest that this is the thing that counts and not the Blue Book is just again trying to mislead Members of the Opposition who may not have that much knowledge about negotiations on constitutional matters. Oh, yes, the Deputy Prime Minister says that he has got a new book and that this is an old one.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: I said a Blue one.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Would he be good enough to lend me that new book which he has? Or is he saying that it is the same one that he now has - that he never had it but now has?

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Which you are having.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Sir, would the Deputy Prime Minister please - I will sit down if he will let me know whether that book of his is something new that contains the P.A.P. jiggery-pokery clause or not? I am prepared to sit down if he will be good enough to explain to me -

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Latest edition.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Oh, the latest edition, Sir.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Reprint.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: May I have the reprint of the latest edition? May I beg the Deputy Prime Minister to be good enough to let me be guided accordingly by the latest edition reprint?

Column: 585



    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Yes. That is the white one.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Therefore I say this, that this Article 30 (2) (b) - the most heinous paragraph (b) has been put in in spite of its having been rejected in London. I do not say the Prime Minister had no right to try and put this in. But the manner in which he tried to put it in is not worthy of a Prime Minister. In his speech, he could have drawn attention to the fact that this was put in not in the Blue book, but in the White book and gave reasons why he wanted to put it in. He just left it at that, hoping that by giving us this document as late as the afternoon of Sunday and wanting us to debate it on Tuesday, they could just bulldoze it through. Article 30 (2) (b) is most reprehensible to this extent, that it has never been the practice in a Parliament where there is no proportional representation. It will be all right in France, as pointed out by the Minister for Law, where they have proportional representation, where the number of votes cast for each political Party will decide the number of seats that political Party shall have in the Legislature. That would have been all right. But ours is not a proportional representation Assembly, Sir. Ours is direct election, a candidate stands for election, he gets elected. It is not necessary that he belongs to a Party. It may be on his own qualifications, and it could be that because of his qualifications and of his association with a political Party that he gets returned. But he is not returned just because he is a member of a political Party. This Article 30 (2) (b) - what is the intention behind it? The Government know 25-25, Sembawang, no by-election. They will not dare to go there. No by-election. They know that they are holding their Members in check because of Malaysia. "Malaysia is coming, behave, boys. If you damage Malaysia, you watch out. You might be like the Barisan Sosialis after 3lst August; they might not be sitting here." They want this particular clause to protect their own party interests in this House. They know that after this Malaysia debate there may be one or two or even more Members walking across to the other side in

Column: 586

disgust. They want this clause just to be able to keep them in check. So, I submit, Sir, that what the P.A.P. is trying to do is not to bring in a new constitution for Singapore, but a new constitution for the P.A.P., in the same way as they had tried to make the national anthem a P.A.P. anthem; in the same way as they had tried to make the national flag a P.A.P. flag; and in the same way as they had tried to make the Yang di-Pertuan Negara a P.A.P. Negara. Even in this they are trying to make everything P.A.P. There is also evidence only recently. The Yang di-Pertuan Negara -

    Mr Speaker: Order. I refer the hon. Member to Standing Order 46, paragraph (8):

    `The conduct of the Sovereign, Members of the Royal Family, or the Yang di-Pertuan Negara shall not be referred to in any circumstances.'

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Yes. I was just trying to explain the attempts of the P.A.P. to make things all their way.

    So this Article 30 (2) (h) , if adopted, is going to make this sacred Constitution for Singapore nothing but a P.A.P. constitution for the People's Action Party to keep their Members in check, to make their Members behave, to make their Members listen obediently to His Master's Voice.

    We oppose the attempt to include this clause into the Constitution and we would urge on the Government, if they really believe in parliamentary democracy and want to practise parliamentary democracy, to drop this one. And we will, as the Member for Farrer Park has said, vote with them. We will vote with them on the Malaysia motion as we have been with them all along on the Malaysia motion.

    Now, coming to the third point, and that is Article 33. This refers to a by-election. The filling of a casual vacancy. Here again, the Member for Farrer Park has found out another jiggery-pokery of the P.A.P. Article 33 of this Blue Book says that the vacancy has to be filled within three months and this Blue Book certainly contains agreement reached between the Singapore

Column: 587

Government, the Federation Government and the U.K Government. Otherwise the U.K. Government would not have dared to publish this and to make this in due course the Singapore Order in Council. A change - three months here becomes indefinitely. And why we object to this is clear, Sir. Experience has shown us that the Government can just hold up the Sembawang by-election for one year and sit pretty. And when they are charged that they are afraid to go to the by-election despite the fact that the Sembawang seat is a very important seat to either the Government or to the Opposition, they say the law says so. The Jaw says the law does not demand that we should have elections tomorrow or the day after or even six months later. Then why is the explanation given by the Deputy Prime Minister and the Minister for Law? He says, "Oh, this is there. It has been there for a long, long time. So why should it not be there?" We resist it now because experience has shown us that with a P.A.P. type of government, this could be used to the advantage of the party in power. Surely in London they must have agreed to these three months, otherwise this could not have been in the Blue Book. They agreed in London three months. They come back and try to make it indefinite. But we would not have minded if they had tried to make it indefinite and brought it openly to this Assembly and said, "Members of the Opposition, we made a mistake. Now we think you should help us, you know. We have been playing Sembawang for one year: let us have this. So we can play for two years." If they had played it straight, it would have been all right. But let us take the opening remarks of the Prime Minister - "I shall be audible. I shall be simple, I shall be straightforward." This is not straightforward, this is the most crooked manner of bringing in things - jiggery-pokery and nothing else. Audible? Yes, he was audible. Simple? That man is never simple. Straightforward? Definitely no. He is not straightforward. So, would it hurt the Government if we say that they should put in a three-month limit to see that a vacant seat is filled?

Column: 588

If they accept the deletion 01 Article 30 (2) (b), if they accept our suggestion that any amendment of the constitution should receive a two-thirds majority votes all these things we ask in the interests of Singapore, in the interests of democracy and fair play. We are not asking for this in the interests of the Alliance. What the P.A.P. want to achieve by this is just to protect the interests of the P.A.P. If they will agree to these amendments, these points that we have brought up, we will vote with them with great pleasure and acclamation that Malaysia is 29 days now from today, and it will be a legal fact. Sure I will leave it. There are Ministers of the Government who will answer to this. But if they do not accept it, may I suggest if it can be done - I do not think it can - that voting on the motion should be in parts, so that where it refers to Malaysia we are 100 per cent with them. But where it refers to jiggery-pokery, we are against them. But if the motion is to be voted as a whole, it would just force the Alliance against their will, against their desire, to abstain from voting. And if we do that, the P.A.P. master distortionists will go out telling the people again, "There you are. The Alliance is against Malaysia." Perhaps the great minds of the Government could help us out. We are sincere. We are with them with Malaysia up to the hilt. Make it easy for us to vote on that. If they insist on puting in this jiggery-pokery, we are going to make it clear to the country that we will not tolerate nor be a party to undemocratic practices intended to prolong the life and protect the interests of any political Party.

    Sir, there is one thing about this loan. The Prime Minister made great play of this loan. He said, "We lend the money to the Borneo territories. No doubt we do not want interest for the first five years on $100 million, but in return for that Singapore is assured of 50 per cent workmen and Singapore contractors going there." So at the Airport, at Hong Lim and even on television, he said. "There you are. I am looking after your interest. All of you workers of Singapore will have a chance to go to Borneo and Sarawak and earn a livelihood." He very bodly said that was the agreement.

Column: 589

Then the Chief Minister-designate of Borneo said, "There has been no such agreement." And straightaway the Prime Minister jumped in, "The Chief Minister-designate of Borneo is wrong. I am right. I have documents to prove it." And what did he produce? Writing on the back of an envelope. This is in Misc. 5 of 1963. Writing on the back of an envelope, a photostat copy of which, it now appears, is not a photostat of the complete writing on the back of the envelope. The Federation Government, it would seem, as pointed out by the previous speakers, has denied that there has been such an agreement. In the speech of the Prime Minister, in moving his motion, I waited patiently for him to state his stand on this 50 per cent workmen. He said nothing. Perhaps his conscience was pricking him and he was trying not to bluff the Opposition as he has tried to bluff the public on the radio and on television.

    Let us try and understand the Prime Minister. What was the big fight that he staged? "We want to see common market terms written into the Constitution." That is good. We are with him when he says that Singapore workmen should be given an opportunity of employment in the Borneo territories. We are with him. That is the right thing. We support him. But with his sharp mind, with his great intellect, surely in the same manner as he had insisted on protection of common market terms in the Constitution, he could have insisted that this should be written into the Constitution.
